column1: The Hungarian reaches of the Mureș/Maros are 73 km (45 mi) long as the state border. Some 28.5 km2 (11.0 sq mi) on the northern side of the river are protected as part of the Körös-Maros National Park. The Maros Floodplain Protected Area consists of gallery forests
column2: floodplain meadows and 0.6 km2 (0.23 sq mi) of forest reserve near Szeged.

column1: Salt used to be traded in medieval times on the river on large rafts.

The river is known to be first mentioned by Herodotus in 484 BC bearing the name Maris (Μάρις). Strabo calls it Marisos (Μάρισος). It was known in Latin as the Marisus;   It is also mentioned in 948 AD
column2: in a document of the Byzantine Emperor Constantine VII

column1: It was also known in German variously as the Mieresch
column3: owing to Transylvanian Saxon settlements and prior Habsburg rule. It was known in Turkish as the Maroş or Muriş under the Ottomans.
